Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Darken the orange buttons for accessibility" (#8219) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
For WCAG 2.1, web components must have a 3:1 contrast ratio. This darkens both the "search" button in the header as well as the "copy" button for installation instructions.

Before:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/94200502-5d65d080-fe6f-11ea-9860-c4ffe1a83351.png)

After:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/94318820-31fde700-ff3e-11ea-914a-e3f74808316a.png)

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8195

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Miss alt attribute for feedback" (#8224) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Title: WCAG 1.1.1: Ensures elements have alternate text or a role of none or presentation (img) Tags: Accessibility, WCAG 1.1.1, image-alt Issue: Ensures elements have alternate text or a role of none or presentation (image-alt - https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.0/image-alt?application=msftAI) Target application: NuGet Gallery | Home - https://www.nuget.org/ Element path: iframe[src=""];img Snippet: How to fix: Fix any of the following: Element does not have an alt attribute aria-label attribute does not exist or is empty aria-labelledby attribute does not exist, references elements that do not exist or references elements that are empty Element has no title attribute or the title attribute is empty Element's default semantics were not overridden with role="presentation" Element's default semantics were not overridden with role="none" Environment: Chrome version 85.0.4183.121 ==== This accessibility issue was found using Accessibility Insights for Web 2.21.1 (axe-core 4.0.1), a tool that helps find and fix accessibility issues. Get more information & download this tool at http://aka.ms/AccessibilityInsights.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "When creating a new API key, glob pattern description for "Alpha.*" is misleading" (#8223) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

When creating a new API key, the glob pattern description for **Alpha.*** is misleading as Alpha.* will select package that begin with "Alpha." not "Alpha" in general.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15097183/94299927-4ccc5d80-ff36-11ea-83a7-68171b90d646.png)

Suggested correction:

- Alpha* will select any package that has an ID beginning with _Alpha_, such as "AlphaCore" or "Alpha.Core"
- Alpha.* will select any package that has an ID beginning with _Alpha.*_, such as "Alpha.Core" or "Alpha.Tools"

### To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use glob pattern "Alpha.*"
2. Get confused when "AlphaCore" is not selected based on the description.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enable seeing ALL "used by" NuGet packages and GitHub repos, not just top 5" (#8222) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?

Today, on the package details page, you can only see the top 5 NuGet packages and GitHub repositories that depend on a package.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/94294651-fac71000-ff14-11ea-9c60-ebcfeba01260.png)

In this example, there are 27.6K other packages that depend on Newtonsoft.Json but there is no way to see them.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add some link, like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/94294267-6b216180-ff14-11ea-97b8-1185866f0240.png)

This could take you to the normal package list used for search or for the profile page but scoped to the dependent list.

It's not clear how the list would look for GitHub repositories.

### Additional context

We have at least one internal partner that has asked for this information. If I recall correctly, several 3rd party customers asked for the full list for the GitHub Used By, which has been a feature for longer.

### Workaround

You can write some code to enumerate the catalog API and find all packages that dependent on a NuGet package.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/api/query-for-all-published-packages

In the package details catalog leaf is a `dependencyGroups` property. For example:
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/data/2020.07.14.15.04.58/microsoft.extensions.dependencymodel.3.1.6.json
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/94294558-dbc87e00-ff14-11ea-8645-64c10256924e.png)

There is no easy way to replicate the GitHub dependents list.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.Server problems to setting up" (#8221) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I have an issue on setting up my private NuGet.Server on a IIS Server.
Please note that the site is using http and https is handle on a F5 part.

The issue is located on the download package feature.
My NuGet.Server instance is accessible at https://myNuget/Feed and a virtual path /Feed is in place on my IIS instance.

During a NuGet restore, the URL called is for example:
https://myNuget/Feed/nuget/Packages(Id='Gelf4Net',Version='2.0.3')
But the download URL delivered by NuGet.Server instance is:
http://myNuget/nuget/Packages(Id='Gelf4Net',Version='2.0.3')/Download
In consequence, the package is not found...

Do you know if it is possible to configure the URL sent by the NuGet.Server in order to request an https URL and with the virtual path /Feed?

Thanks for your help.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enabled structured logging for metrics in NuGet.Build.Tasks" (#10072) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
MSBuild has an API [`IBuildEngine5.LogTelemetry`](https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/blob/aed5e7ed0b7e031d3e486c63b206902bf825b128/src/Framework/IBuildEngine5.cs#L18) which does **not** send any telemetry, but allows any MSBuild loggers passed in on the command line, which receive [`IDictionary<string, string>` property bags](https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/blob/aed5e7ed0b7e031d3e486c63b206902bf825b128/src/Build/BackEnd/Components/Logging/ILoggingService.cs#L502). This allows anyone writing a MSBuild logger to more easily capture NuGet restore metrics, without having to do string parsing.

NuGet already has some telemetry infrastructure can be reused:
* Restore already calls `NuGet.Common.TelemetryActivity.EmitTelemetryEvent`, which is a no-op outside of Visual Studio.
* Therefore, `RestoreTask` can create its own implementation of `INuGetTelemetryService` which calls MSBuild's `LogTelemetry`
* RestoreTaskEx (static graph restore) is probably going to be much more tricky. Need to investigate how logging works there, but the same concept applies.

This allows anyone interested, particularly Microsoft's internal engineering system teams, to pass their custom MSBuild logger on the command line, and it can receive more detailed performance information, and easily obtain numbers without having to do string parsing, regex, substring, etc.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Replace remaining XAML-drawn icons with Image Service icons" (#10071) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**Blocked by**: https://devdiv-design.visualstudio.com/D3%20Studio/_workitems/edit/12595
Remove and replace XAML-drawn icons with Image Service, once they are available per this blocking issue.  

Cancel/Download are available today, but are very thin and may not work well in our UI. I believe new icons are being created per issue.
For the ones that already had close matches, they'll be removed as part of https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/9789

## Cancel option?
I did find a possible replacement for the Cancel ("X"), but it's very thin and may be too difficult to see. (particularly on Dark theme). Code change: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/06902c0a18d480f962295c3cde602a2733ccbb23. 

@JonDouglas can comment on these samples:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374270-17ac4080-00d9-11eb-96e0-0c8f42319a6f.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374273-19760400-00d9-11eb-8428-548725f3f93d.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374277-1b3fc780-00d9-11eb-9848-73643fde41a0.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374278-1c70f480-00d9-11eb-98de-7cb6e6b88c7a.png)

## XAML-drawn icons which don't currently have close matches in ImageService:
Icon | PackageIconMonikers | src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.PackageManagement.UI\Xamls\
-- | -- | --
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374239-d7e55900-00d8-11eb-94a4-192f788e9433.png)¬† | PrefixReservedIndicator | PrefixReservedIndicator.xaml
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374246-e5024800-00d8-11eb-8a49-b681b222b679.png) | UpdateAvailableIndicator | UpdateAvailableIndicator.xaml
¬† 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374251-ea5f9280-00d8-11eb-9dd8-6b8c224d7178.png) | UninstallIndicator | UninstallIndicator.xaml
¬†
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/94374253-ee8bb000-00d8-11eb-96e4-5087b9c4bede.png) | DownloadIndicator | DownloadIndicator.xaml

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget PMUI throws StreamJsonRPC exception" (#10070) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
Not sure if it's regression.

1. Open Nuget.Client source code in VS
2. Install Text2Xml(v 1.1.0) package into all projects.
3. Try to downgrade Text2Xml(v 1.0.1) version.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget PMC memory usage - Add new telemetries to track events related to PMC and Powershell usage." (#10069) at NuGet/Home

Recently decided not to act on [decrease PMC usage](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9988) issue. We suspect it's highly unlikely problem to happen. To better understand this problem we add this telemetries.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve the no-op hashing performance" (#10068) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently the no-op hash is calculated by creating a json string of the dependency graph spec for said project. 
This involves a lot of duplicate + using jsonwriter for hash is not ideal.

This issue tracks the investigation for improving that hashing performance.

I discussed with @cristinamanum and @zivkan 

The suggestion is move to a normal hashing function instead of using the package specwriter. 
The challenge is that we don't know if the package spec is mutated during restore.

Given that here are the options. 

* Consider setting a Locked property, to disable mutation after a certain point.
* Use an intermediate class that can generate the hashcode on demand (this will require coordination to ensure the hash generation is synchronized).
* Restore Runner before invoking the restore command can prepopulate the hash code for all the package specs. 

This is expected to be a long investigation, because while perf is one goal, we need to ensure this doesn't get regressed in the future. 

I did prototype these changes and it showed a significant improvement for large slns with deep project graphs, up to 2-4x faster hash generation. The hash generation right now is about ~30% of the time spent in the restore part (not dg spec generation). 

So cmd could see numbers like 7s to 6.8s, but VS will relatively better perf, example, 1.1s -> 900ms.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Enhance telemetry with new information" (#10067) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
Enhance the existing telemetry events with information for:

- [ ] CommitAsync duration

- [ ] Graph - WalkAsync duration

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Show requested version in the Solution Level UI" (#9827) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we only show the installed version in the Solution Level, we are going to add a column "Requested" version. 
It only applies to PackageReference projects.
